0.suggestion: Develop and communicate a clear plan to address the homeless crisis in Bellingham.

Provide information on the requirements to make the 'streateries' a permanent feature.

123.suggestion: Designate parking spaces in areas like Railroad and Holly only for people with disabilities and those who cannot walk long distances.
Restrict or regulate parking usage to ensure spaces are available for people with disabilities.
Ensure continued access to parking close to destinations for people with accessibility needs.

124.suggestion: Reduce annual fees associated with streateries to encourage thriving local businesses and outdoor community spaces.
Maintain or consider increasing fees for streateries to encourage responsible business practices.
Reconsider the plan to increase fees and permits for streateries.
Maintain reasonable fees for streateries to ensure affordability for all owners.

125.suggestion: Enforce standards for accessibility, safety, and spacing for streateries to address community concerns.
Design standards for streateries should be established and enforced to improve their appearance.
Require streateries to fulfill architectural guidelines similar to those for permanent structures.
Establish a standard of construction for streateries to ensure quality and safety.

126.suggestion: Subsidize businesses to take over parking.
Businesses should pay market rate to take over parking spaces for streateries, rather than a subsidized rate.

127.suggestion: Limit the number of parking spaces that streateries can occupy.
Determine and set a city-wide acceptable limit on parking spaces that can be converted to streateries.

128.suggestion: Limit the amount of parking a business can use relative to the total available spaces in front of the building.
Prevent businesses from using parking spaces that reduce availability for neighboring businesses.

129.suggestion: Provide clear signage indicating the locations of public restrooms.
Provide clear signage indicating the location of restrooms.
Ensure restrooms are easily accessible and well-marked.

130.suggestion: Increase the number of public restrooms available in the area.
Increase the number of women's restrooms to reduce wait times.

131.suggestion: Make the pump track a permanent feature in the park plans.
Preserve the pump track as a cultural and recreational space for families and the community.
Make the pump track a permanent part of the park in the Lettered Streets neighborhood.
Promote the pump track from an interim use to a permanent design element.
Prevent the removal of the pump track to make way for privately held buildings to preserve public benefit.

132.suggestion: Install vertical posts for the bike lanes on Meridian.
Install vertical posts for the bike lanes on Illinois.

133.suggestion: Ensure that Option 2 of the Master Plan fully protects Landmark Trees located directly north of the Sportsplex from development impacts.
Commit to protecting all Landmark Trees at the Civic Athletic Complex in line with protections required of residents and private developers in public development projects.

134.suggestion: Develop a plan to preserve mature trees during development or construction.
Ensure the plan includes measures to protect mature trees from being lost to developments like the Meridian development.

136.suggestion: Implement a tax on landlords who own more than a certain number of dwelling units.

137.suggestion: Review the necessity of '15 Ton Limit' signs on every bridge.
Assess whether the number of '15 Ton Limit' signs can be reduced.

138.suggestion: Keep the current temporary entrance sign as it is, since it is visible and stylish.
Keep the existing sign as it is because it is readable to motorists.

139.suggestion: Use the money for renovations and maintenance instead of a new sign.
Use the $75k budget for park repairs instead of a new sign.

140.suggestion: Assess and consider the actual usage of the new bike lane.
Evaluate if the bike lane is justified based on bike usage data.

141.suggestion: Avoid narrowing or reducing car lanes on Lakeway to prevent increased speeding and dangerous lane changes.
Do not reduce traffic lanes on Lincoln or Lakeway.
Do not reduce the number of vehicle traffic lanes in the Lakeway freeway underpass project.
Consider widening the Lakeway underpass as part of the project.
Consider constructing a new freeway underpass or tunnel specifically for bikes and pedestrians to avoid further restricting the existing Lakeway underpass.

142.suggestion: Explore alternative solutions to improve bike safety on Lakeway without reducing car lanes.
Improve safety measures at the Lakeway and Electric intersection to better protect cyclists from turning motorists.
Implement traffic controls or redesign the intersection to reduce dangerous uncontrolled left turns from Lakeway to Electric.

143.suggestion: Add bike lanes without reducing existing traffic lanes.
Allow adding bike lanes without sacrificing existing vehicle lanes.

144.suggestion: Eliminate the free right turn on red from BM Parkway heading east onto Samish Way to reduce lane blockage and traffic congestion on Samish Way southbound.
Eliminate the free right turn from I5 south exit onto Samish Way to reduce traffic issues.

145.suggestion: Develop future plans for Fouts Park.
Improve the playground at Fouts Park.
Enhance the landscaping at Fouts Park.

146.suggestion: Implement paid parking on South Cornwall.
Install parking meters on South Cornwall.

147.suggestion: Analyze data on parking volume during December when parking was free.
Analyze data on length of parking during December when parking was free.
Analyze data on merchants' satisfaction during December when parking was free.
Analyze data on residents' satisfaction during December when parking was free.

148.suggestion: The City should provide accommodations for residents of low-income housing impacted by newly mandated paid parking.
The City should implement measures to mitigate the cost burden of paid parking on low-income households.

149.suggestion: Implement enforcement measures to ensure compliance with the three-foot passing law.
Increase public awareness about the three-foot passing law through education and outreach programs.

150.suggestion: Add a walking path on James Street to improve pedestrian safety.
Add a walking path on Hannegan to improve pedestrian safety.
Widen or improve the existing narrow path on Hannegan to make it safer for pedestrians.

151.suggestion: Make Bellingham's regulations for creating ADUs less restrictive, similar to Seattle and Tacoma.
Increase transparency by publishing Bellingham's ADU regulations for the general public.

152.suggestion: Provide a map showing areas proposed as high density designation.
If a map is not available, provide information on areas expected to be designated as high density.

153.suggestion: Clarify whether a high density designation allows developers to build higher than existing height restrictions.
Clarify whether higher density means only smaller unit sizes without increasing building height.

154.suggestion: Do not implement the Urban Forest Plan.
Ensure that the Urban Forest Plan does not make development and building housing more difficult or unaffordable.

155.suggestion: The city should improve protection for mature trees.
The city should establish clear, enforceable laws to protect mature trees.
